posts.cooked: My team is working on a new robot for the upcoming off-season as part of our advanced CAD program. We’re nearing completion when we encountered a part that may not be feasible to manufacture with our current resources—it either requires excessive time, energy, or results in waste. Our CNC setup is the Laguna CNC, using 6061 aluminum. The part uses ⅛-inch, 4mm, and 6mm heads, is constructed from a 35mm aluminum plate, and employs special clamps for precise positioning. The CAD model currently lacks filets, which raises concerns about manufacturability.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: This would be an easier part to make on a mill I recommend uploading a copy of this part to OnShape for people to look at in depth.
From what you can see in this photo, would you think it’s possible to manufacture without resources?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Most of the machines I see are CNC routers. Do you have multiple axes, or is it just a standard router?

posts.name: Weston Bosworth
posts.cooked:
The text contains multiple HTML elements that need to be removed to clean it up. Here is the processed text:

we have ⅛, 4, 6 inch heads for the cnc. you have .125 endmills and 4/6 inch facemills. did you mean to say 1/8, 1/4, and 1/6th endmills? what other tools do you have? any drills?

where are you planning on adding filets? to me, this part looks like you want to machine what’s in the picture, and hand deburr afterwards. adding cosmetic filets in the wrong places could drastically increase the difficulty of the part.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
Um. May I suspect the designer is a 3D printing enthusiast? Fixturing is going to be quite a challenge. I think you need to cut into all six faces. On a router you will need to start with "make a fixture that can repeatably orient and secure your part in all required orientations". That would likely be easier on a mill... but still do-able on a stiff router. You should take a quick peek at Patrick’s video on making crazy parts for the SDS MK5.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: The depth of cut on many features appears too deep relative to the feature size. The central hole requires a larger end mill. Using carbide tools is essential; otherwise, flexibility may damage the workpiece.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Drop it in an automated CNC quoting interface like Protolabs or Xometric. If there's a serious issue, it'll let you know. You'll also get a price for manufacturing the part. Then you can weigh the $ vs team hours decision in a quantifiable way.
Only three axes

what does this mean? you have .125 endmills , and 4/6 inch facemills? did you mean to say 1/8, 1/4, and 1/6th endmills? what other tools do you have? any drills  
⅛inch endmills, 4 and 6 millimeter endmills. As far as i know we don’t really have good drills

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
I would guess this is the part from 2910’s cad release, but not completely sure  
2025 Top Level Assembly  
3296×2547 2.52 MB  

Team 2910 is excited to present the CAD and tech binder for our 2025 robot Spectre. [IMG_3689]  
CAD  
Tech Binder
Yes it is

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: I don’t see why not. It’s just going to cause pain, and you may end up discarding some materials, but if you’re creating one, there likely isn’t a physical barrier, especially since 2910 has already crafted an identical prototype. These are the exciting and challenging tasks to undertake during the offseason to gauge your potential.

These are the rear bearing blocks for the telescope, which are quite challenging to manufacture. They involve numerous setup steps, but they remain feasible on a 3-axis CNC mill using just a vice with parallel bars—no additional fixtures required. It will require significant time and effort to properly set up and run the part, making the process somewhat tedious.
DFM

posts.name: David | 8866 A | Manufacturing+Hardware
posts.cooked:
If you want to perform it using only a 3-axis machine, it could be feasible though likely quite challenging. We have a Laguna CNC that we utilize for robotics, and I wouldn't feel comfortable attempting that particular aspect on our setup. If I were responsible for this part, given the resources available here—such as high-quality workholding systems, probes, and 5-axis machines—it would be extremely straightforward. Not suggesting that it's impossible, but have you considered how you'd secure and measure the part precisely? If so, I'd be interested in seeing your approach.

Additionally, access to the CAD model of the part via OnShape would greatly aid in figuring out the best way forward.

posts.name: Eitan
posts.cooked: While redesigning the 2910 arm, I improved its design to require fewer setups. By splitting the part into the main component and two distinct bearing holders, I achieved this optimization. This change ensures that the assembly process now needs only three CNC setups—from the back, right, and left—and a straightforward milling machine setup for the two screw holes that secure the horizontal bearings. Despite remaining challenging, I believe a 3-axis CNC machine can successfully execute this design. Additionally, while 2910 may have produced similar bearing caps, my modification involved truncating the redundant support structure.

posts.name: Patrick Woolfenden
posts.cooked: Important Notice: All participants must register by the end of this week. This is a critical deadline, so please ensure everyone has registered promptly.

posts.name: Logan de Laar
posts.cooked: By the look of it, this appears to be a non-structural component solely holding bearings. Given your CNC capabilities, machining this piece would likely be too time-consuming and costly. While possible, it’s advisable to redesign it incorporating both 3D-printed parts and metal, potentially allowing the entire part to be manufactured from nylon-carbon fiber.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Redesigning it to include 3D printed parts and metal together If you’re willing to wait a bit and spend money there’s another option available. You can upload an STL file to a service which typically charges a fee and returns a metal part after some time. This process usually takes about a third of the build season making it less convenient during the build period. However if you’re planning an offseason build where you have the time you might consider it.

data.title: Is it possible to manufacture this part?
